If you just finished your reprap or repstrap or any other cool self made 3D printer, you must be very thirsty! I know that because I was too. So you can start with a beer while tweaking your printer to print really fine and cool stuff.
This will cost you a whole lot of swet too and you will be thirsty again, so you definitely need a drink! Read below how to get a good one...

• Print a bunch of cocktail sticks (to calibrate your machine) --> use PLA plastic, this is non-toxic
  • As soon as they are fine, print some more :)
  • If you have printed enough of them, read on...
    • DRINK:
  • Get some rum (at least 3 Year aged.. ;) 7 works also), fresh mint, limes, cane sugar and ice cubes
  • Cut the limes in pieces, and put into glass together with some sugar.
  • Squash the limes
  • Clap your hands (with mint in between) and put the mint into glass
  • Fill glass with ice
  • Top up with rum (if you're not a really hard guy, mix with soda)
  • Stir with one of your new cocktail sticks and enjoy :)
    • PS: They printed fine with my 0.5mm nozzle. Perhaps they could be made more detailed with a 0.35mm nozzle...?!

remixed_from.title: High Strength Paracord Block and Tackle Pulley

title: Block and Tackle (Pully system) for 550 paracord.

description.text:
I needed to make a block and tackle system that I could use to lift my deer feeders high into the trees. This is what I came up with. The frame is designed to prevent the paracord from slipping off of the wheel and the body is designed to be well fitted so the rope cannot slip in between any spaces and get jammed.

This is a double sheave design so it will give you 4 pounds of lift for every one pound of pull. This can be modified to hold three sheaves (just use an additional center piece with another sheave) and that will give you 6 pounds of lift for every pound of pull.

This has been tested at 150 pounds without issue. I am confident it will lift a lot more but you do so at your own risk, as I have not tested it.

View it in action here: https://youtu.be/Aj3af8e8Vz0

I printed this with a 50% infill. I would not go below 30% but I guess you could if you were making this for a very light lift. Use this item at your own risk.

Parts:
(4) 2.5" long 5/16-18 bolts
(2) 2.5" long 1/4-20 bolts (these are for the pulley sheaves -aka: wheels)
(4) 5/16-18 locking nuts
(2) 1/4-20 locking nuts

remixed_from.author: droftarts
remixed_from.title: Parametric pulley - lots of tooth profiles

description.text:
A replacement for the smooth idlers that come (or used to come) with ORD Bot kits. It fits the same two bearings and is a drop-in replacement.  
Slice with 2 perimeter layers @ 0.30-0.32 mm skin thickness, layer thickness 0.15-0.17. 50% infill worked fine for me. Print two at once if your cooling is not up to the task.  
Why replace the original idlers? Well, for one, because they have a flat lip instead of a conical one and cause the belt teeth to rub and clip against the edge. Also, because they tended to cause belt slippage upwards, which made the belts rub against the bottom of the Y plate.  
This is the GT2 idler, if someone needs an MXL, let me know and i'll make another version.

The Knolahri are a random alien species from Wayfarer. They live in an ocean world and inhabit the sparse atolls and reefs. The Knolahri are technologically advanced and use magic to enhance their tech. Currently, they are seeking to capitalize on their world's only natural resource: Time. Their world's relative time stream is 82 times faster than the mean. So, spending 82 days on Knolahr only equates to 1 day on most worlds.They are ramping up to be a vacation destination. High society only.

In Wayfarer: Things Beyond Wonder, fantasy, science fiction, and cosmic horror combine into a sprawling multiverse where nearly anything is possible. Grounded with an intuitive RPG system designed with foundations in real-world physics, Wayfarer allows players and GM's to create the characters and stories they want right out of the gate.

The Wayfarer rules codex is available for purchase on our website, illgottengames.net

It is a connection between a bearing of D25 (Diameter 25) and a spool diameter between 50 and 70.

Print it twice with the small face on the plate.

Glue the outer ring of the bearing into each part.

For the axle, do :

  • Nut
  • Part with bearing
  • Spool
  • Part with bearing
  • Nut

Be sure to screw it tight enough so that the spool won't fall.

customizable (once i add the necessary comments around the variables) 90° joint for openbeams.

It is an endcap for one beam and the other slides through the slot. Thus one of the beams is adjustable, or it can join in the middle of a beam.

Print it with the extrusion width you specify in customizer.
2x extrusion width is added to all inside dimensions to allow for abs shrinkage and nozzle width.

author: GiovanH

description.text:
A parametric buckle for connecting and tensioning two flat lines. The knot shown in the picture slips in one direction only - if you apply tension to the inner of the two line ends. If the tension is equal or larger on the outer line, it is self-locking. Not safe for any purpose, but I tensioned mine (10mm bars, solid print) up to some 5kN. Parameters:
  • Line width, bar diameter, overall length, tolerance
  • Offset from center (working with thick lines requires more spacing in the center)
    • Feel free to flattr this if it makes loose ends meet for you.

Adjust scad file, print, buckle up.
The STL provided is good for a 30mm line.

title: Local Motors Labs Skull Badge
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: Inspired by the Hack a Day badge (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1562), we wanted to have a physical badge we could print to give to LM Labs members, but intitial responses were that we should have a skull and wrenches that were more realistic. So, using SSd's cleaned skull as a base, I modeled one of our wrenches, mirrored it, added it to the assembly file, and voila! Future revisions may include a void in the skull for pausing the print and adding an RFID coin to use as a key for Labs access. What is LM Labs? It is the automotive themed hackerspace where community members can come work on their own projects, and help develop future Local Motors vehicles.
Have been successful printing at 0.27 mm layer thickness with 2 shells and 10% infill.

description.text:
Landing gear that I printed to keep my ZMR250 racing quad elevated when it lands. (Designed to be light)

For anybody interested, here is my build info

Glass-Fiber ZMR250 frame
DYS 1806-2300KV motors
BLHELI ESCs (20 Amp)
naze32 flight controller
5x4.5 props
D8R-II plus radio reciever
Taranis plus radio transmitter
1500 mAH 35-70C battery
No FPV (though looking to upgrade in the coming months)

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.1 mm

Infill:

100%

Notes:

For maximum strength, use the settings above.

There are 3 files. V1, 2, and 3. Use V1 first. If the landing gear flops around too much for your liking, print V2. It is slightly heavier, so it is less preferred for racing. If you would like your landing gear to be mounted closer to the motors, print V3. The spacing is slightly smaller, enough to make a significant difference to the distance across the legs.

If you want to store the battery underneath the quad, use the V4 gear, which allows plenty of room to strap a battery to the bottom of the quad.

author: jlavp

description.text:
Convert the sheep china gimbal (GLB Hobby) from gopro mount to Sony AZ1 mount. Az1 camera is a good and affordable flight camera. The form factor also allows the lens to be more forward from the GoPro camera and therefore less propellers in the picture.

I bought my gimbal I converted here: http://www.banggood.com/FPV-2-Axis-Brushless-Gimbal-With-Controller-For-DJI-Phantom-GoPro-3-p-908068.html
Fits on DJI Phantom like copters.

Ready to fly weight including camera and lensprotector =273g
Total height = 92mm

I also made a 3-axis gimbal located here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:955071

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=L4lc0UNaGDY

Print the three parts and use the vibration dampening from the sheep banggood gimble.

CamHolder_Inf20_01: I used 20% infill and 0.25mm height settings. Supports on the overhang and in the big hole.

HorizontalArm_Inf13_01: I used 13% infill and 0.25mm height. It need to be rolled 180 deg from the picture. Only supports in the big vertical hole.

UpperArm_2axis_wPlate_01.STL: 13% infill or less and 0.25mm height should be good. Designed to fit the original vibration dampening plate.

On all parts I used 205 Celsius deg. PLA.

Use the old screws from the gimbal. Countersunk M3x6 (8pcs.). M2x8 (9pcs.). And suitable M3s on the top yaw motor.

The controller can be screwed or glued with double sided tape (servo tape).

title: HooptieJ's OneUp and TwoUp Extruder Housing *Updated Files 8/19*

description.text:
updated 8/19: Fixed manifold, uploaded B(ack) and F(ront) versions of the file for those that arent comfortable mirroring in software.

Updated 8/12: with Modified Tension arm and an even more vented/slimmed housing model, with additional support around the tension bolt-hole.

For my first big print- i made Markqv's replacement extruder, and wow - it worked so much better than the stock one -

then i found the "v8" and the 3Up housing - and while they each addressed some of the issues i had with markqv's - it missed the most glaring one-

The Two Up is now shipping a "V2" design, which uses completely different extruder tension springs and hardware-

the MarkQv and the "v8" and the 3Up use the old v1 springs and hardware -

  • So i Bring you - HooptieJ's Two UP extruder carriage-

I liked the "venting" on the 3up , since i had visibility and heat creep issues with Markqv - but the 3up's wiper box was not something i was interested in and the tension arm angle from the v8 didnt work for my fan mounting-

Based Heavily on marqvs extruder - i added some vent windows to the top and left side - and moved the bolt bracing the tension arm, and removed some (now useless) case .

using ALL ORIGINAL hardware from the V2 kit - no extra bolts or screws or springs - enjoy!

the motor Spacer is here:

Also markQV - http://www.thingiverse.com/download:1123617

and the carriage/X bearing mount is

  • here - http://www.thingiverse.com/download:1123622 from the same markqv build.

Updated: with Modified Tension arm and an even more vented/slimmed housing model, with additional support around the tension bolt-hole.

This is a simple plate for mounting the back of a Nema 17 stepper motor on to a piece of 2020 extrusion. I used it to mount an Ormerod extruder on my Kossel frame. To use it, remove 2 screws from the back of the stepper motor, and replace them with longer M3 screws passed through the plate (you need 35mm length cap head screws for a 34mm long motor). Then secure the plate to the extrusion using two M4 screws.

description.text: A quick print (approx. 2 min) that allows for items to easily be attached to a key ring. Prints with Ninjaflex or similar flexible filaments.

Designed in OpenSCAD, this wand-shaped reading light was inspired by the Harry Potter series and was made for a friend as a going away gift. The casing comes in three parts, and houses a small blue LED, a 51 Ohm resistor, a tall tactile button, and two AAA batteries. The assembly included welding the top two parts together with spare filament and a soldering iron, but I will update with better tolerances soon. Feel free to paint and decorate however you'd like to make it your own. The wand stand was printed separately but fits the wand perfectly.

Tools:
3D Printer
Soldering Iron
Wire Cutters

Materials:
Printed Parts
2 AAA batteries
1 small LED (color may vary)
1 51 Ohm resistor
1 tall tactile button
Wire
Solder
Thin Copper foil
Spring or other metal device to make contact with batteries
Paint

Assembly:

  • Print at .2 layer height, with 20-25% infill.
  • Connect the LED to the resistor and a long wire (longer than 10 in.)
  • Solder an additional wire an just longer than the tip piece to the resistor. This will attach to the button.
  • Solder two thin strips of copper foil to the pins on the button, thes will allow easier connection to the rest of the circuit.
  • Use tweasers or pliers to insert the button from the top of the shaft piece and through the hole above the full sphere.
  • Use a generous amount of solder to connect the top foil piece to the plastic wall around it and let cool, securing the button in place.
    connect the shorter wire from the tip to the top of the button and feed the long wire through the excess space in the tube.
  • Insert the AAA batteries from the bottom of the base
  • Connect spring to wire at the bottom.
  • Close cap over bottom to secure the spring against the batteries and complete the circuit.
  • If the light works with the button push, hold the tip against the base and weld together using soldering iron. Insert a spare length of filament for a stronger weld.
  • Paint
  • Cast Spells

title: Anti-loss ring for rubber bumpers, used in motorbike top case racks (Givi)

description.text:
You might recognize this, if you're an owner of a motorbike with a luggage rack... :-)

I've frequently lost those small rubber bumpers intended for the top case, from the luggage rack of my motorbike. It's a Givi rack and it's perfect ... apart from the holes with which the rubber bumpers are held in place: these are produced just to large & they hardly clamp the rubber bumpers at all.

So, I figured to do something about it & these 3D printed anti-loss rings are doing the job just fine.

Please note: In case you don't have a 3D printer, you'd probably also be able to reach the same thing with the right washer, but those would need to be pretty thin, then - you'd preferably need to try and find washers of 0.5 mm thick, with 6,5 mm bore.

Hope this helps! :-)
Produced it on a Vertex K8400 3D printer, using PLA (1.75mm) filament.

description.text: This is a simple friction fit adapter for connecting an Adafruit Neopixel Strip to power, ground and signal wires without solder. I needed this because I'm not always at a location where I have a soldering station -it is not meant as a permanent connection method. Its very simple and relies on the elasticity of the plastic to provide a nice tension fitting that's just tight enough to hold the wires against the Neopixel strip's contacts.

Printing instructions:
I printed this on a Makerbot Replicator 2 using Matterhackers Natural PLA with a 200um layer thickness, 1 shell, 100% infill and a temperature of 205 degrees C. You definitely want the piece to be solid because you are relying on the elasticity of the plastic to hold the wires against their contacts.

Assembly Instructions:
Strip your wires (solid core 22 AWG only please) and feed them into the assembly - there are guide holes that the wires should align with. Bend the wires back against the plastic as shown in the build pictures. Then feed the Neopixel strip into the slit in the plastic so the wires contact the contact pads. Note, there are different Neopixel strips out there that may vary in the size and shape of the contact pads - this design works well for the Neopixel strips I bought, which are the 60 pixels / meter strips.

Be careful to fortify the wires within the fitting to 1) make sure they don't move around and 2) make sure they don't short against each other. I use hot-glue along the top and back of the fitting to secure the wires in their position.

Also note that since some printers squish the first layer of plastic, the slit provided for the Neopixel strip will be slightly more open on one end than the other. My design tries to take advantage of that making the fitting squize the wires more tightly against the contact pads towards the end sitting on the build plate. If your printer does that as well, make sure you feed the Neopixel strip in from the top (using its print orientation).

title: Gamecube "Gem" Insert
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I just picked up a Gamecube this weekend and it was in less than stellar condition. My biggest issue was the big hole where the Nintendo Gamecube logo should be.

The solution? An insert to fill the hole!

Mine is printed on a Davinci 1.0, .1mm layer with 30% infill. It could probably fare better at 50% on account that the Davinci succks when applying the top layer of a flat surface.

It's a very snug fit, but will go in with force and will stay put without any adhesive.

title: Makerboard Game #1: TwixT/Reversi/Go (and more?)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
The whole idea of my makerboard originated when I decided to make a TwixT game, so naturally this should be the first game to post as well.
During the past few weeks of having this lying around, I have also used the pieces for a couple of other games including Reversi and Go - let me know if you guys come up with anything else!

Many thanks to peyrol for his POV-ray image on boardgamegeek.com!

P.S.: also check out http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:909397 which I designed to serve as a box for these pieces :-)

The corners serve as handicap pieces for TwixT or as board boundaries in other games (e.g. for marking the 8x8 square used for Reversi).

I printed 50 pegs and 50 bridges of each color, but a few less would be sufficient for most games I suppose. The X-Box holds 2x50 bridges and 2x40 pegs, so I got rid of some faulty ones I made in the early design phase.

Printed everything in PLA with 0.3 mm layers, no supports needed. Have fun!

comments.author: unreal_ed

comments.text: It looks way cool, and I'm happy to see that piece design in physical form. Thanks for your hard work! 25 links for each player might conceivably not be enough, though. I'm confused about the handicapping corners. Handicapping tokens that I have seen use just one hole, not three. It appears your tokens use holes which are supposed to be available for one side or the other to place a peg. Do you use an alternate rule set?
comments.author: peyrol

comments.text: My bad, I just checked and actually printed 50 links - it's been a while :-P
comments.author: peyrol

comments.text: It is of course your design, but if you want to indicate the border lines with your handicap tokens, you don't need to use up any hole in the playing field in order to do so. IMO it does matter, a lot. Even if those holes are never actually played in during the game, your design interferes with the process of reading the position. If you look at my crude top down image here: https://boardgamegeek.com/image/2634447/twixter you will see a possible alternate design which occupies only one hole, the new corner hole which is outside the playing area. Use whatever colors you want. Does it make sense to you? It won't be locked in place as securely as it would be if it used three holes. Place it carefully and it should work just fine. And you need only two such pieces, mirror images of each other. The other two corners could be corners of the board.
comments.author: LokusArts

comments.text: Yup, that does make sense...I'll have another thought about your handicap token but won't be ableto design anything for the next few weeks. As for the grooves: they are not very deep so I won't put any pieces in there - they would get lost in an instant :-D
comments.author: peyrol

comments.text: The grooves don't have to be deep. These corner pieces I'm talking about, which are to be used in an even game, could be the same size and look just like the handicap tokens I'm talking about, but without the red part that attaches to a hole. They just have ridges on the underside that fit into the grooves, so you place them in the corners and they stay put. In a handicap game, you would still use two of those corner pieces, and you would also have two handicap tokens. Suppose, for example, you follow the convention that in Twixt, white moves first and white always receives any handicap. So, looking at my diagram, that would mean that your board would have vertical grooves where the handicap tokens indicate the black border rows. The black part of each handicap token could have a ridge on the underside, to help lock them in place. Maybe I should draw better diagrams to show what I'm trying to say. I will get back to you about this. I greatly appreciate your receptive attitude!
comments.author: LokusArts

comments.text: I would like to design my own thingverse Twixt corner and handicap pieces for your board, which you would be most welcome to use if you wish. This would be my first foray into designing something for thingverse. I notice, on your "Makerboard Universal Base" page, you mention that you don't actually print out the 25cm x 25 cm board, and it looks better made with wood. That sounds logical to me, but if I'm going to make these pieces with ridges on the underside that will fit into the grooves you cut, I need to know three values. Please, how wide are these grooves, what is the distance from the center line of a groove to the center line of the nearby border row, and how far apart are adjacent rows (from center line to center line)? Thanks very much!
comments.author: peyrol

comments.text: Using the same pegs you could also play Pente. Fun. Simple rules like Go. Easy to learn, much harder to master. I've been beaten by a five year old!

description.text: This is a bracket with screw mounts for an inexpensive door alarm that only used double stick tape for mounting and the tape kept failing. There are two versions for different screw locations.

These brackets are designed for a specific door alarm sold by Harbor Freight. (http://www.harborfreight.com/door-window-entry-alarm-94983.html) They are very inexpensive alarms (2 in a package for $4.99) but lack a screw mounting option. I am mounting them inside a cabinet door in the kitchen to try and deter the dog from getting in the trash can! I have associated the alarm with a negative consequence. Don't worry it's only getting sprayed with water. The big sissy hates to get wet. I didn't want to improve the latch because I didn't want the cabinets getting torn up by a persistent pooch. Anyway the inside of the cabinet door is not flush and not smooth so the double sided foam tape on the alarm would not hold. The brackets support just enough of the weight to keep the alarms in place. I also added a a couple of bits of double sided foam tape to the sides of the alarm to stick it in the bracket. It hasn't been long but so far the trash has stayed inside the cabinet!

author: btyates

description.text:
Drawn in (inches), this is a bunch of gears and parts that I used in a
moving gear art piece I made for my son. Gears are loose fitting.
Includes an arcamedes screw with pinion gears, a piston and cylinder
and connecting rod and an air tank with gauge. I used a 12 volt, 10
RPM geared motor to run it. Some holes are for shoulder screws
and some are for bearings. I mounted everything on 1/4" acrylic.
I used "Gunmetal" Metalizer paint with smudges of "Rust" paint to
make parts look like rusty metal. I wish I could upload the video of
it running it's very cool. A lot of fun for you bored printers. Sorry about the inch drawing. I'll be danged if I'm going to redraw it in mm. Enjoy.
There is a picture of it. You take it from there.

remixed_from.author: LokusArts
remixed_from.title: Makerboard - Universal Base for Custom Board Games

title: Makerboard Game #2: German-Style Pachisi
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
A great cross and circle game for two to four players (see instructions here).

Pretty much any models can be used as game pieces, just scale them to fit on a 2 cm circular base! I used Makerbot's Aztec chief (42 % scale), Saf's Low Poly Owl Statue (can't remember the scale...), FLOWALISTIK's Low Poly Squirtle (50 % scale) and 3DHubs's King Marvin (90 % scale).

1) Make yourself a makerboard
2) print the background pieces four times in a rather subtle color
3) print the color pieces once in each of the four colors you like best
4) think of cool figurines, scale them to fit on a 2 cm circular base and print 4 of each color
5) print a die if you don't already have one and start playing!

no supports needed, prints very well in PLA with 0.3 mm layers

title: Wayfarer Tactics: Modular Terrain System (Simple Stonework)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Hey everyone! Well, it's Kickstarter time again here at Ill Gotten Games and to kick it off, here's a new set of modular tactics tiles for use with our new game, Wayfarer Tactics (check out the Kickstarter campaign here!) (or any other 28mm wargame or tabletop RPG.)

Wayfarer Tactics is a dynamic miniature wargaming system. With these rules, you can use models from your collection to enact skirmishes, large-scale battles, or party-centered dungeon crawls. Based loosely on our Wayfarer multiverse setting, you can stage your battles in worlds of magic-rich high fantasy, far-flung intergalactic scifi, or anything in between.

Check out our Kickstarter Video!

In addition, we've set up a Patreon page for anyone who's interested to help fund us so we can keep making free and open sourced games like Wayfarer Tactics. Check it out here.

Enjoy!
Printed at a .2 layer height with 15% infill

Hi visitors!
Since I am developing my website currently, I encourage you to visit my website and leave comments there! <3 :) ]

This house was created when I was helping a woman (AgMan) in her "fairy garden" project. We make the design together on tinkercad.
I thought it turned out cute so it would be nice to share with people over here.
You can cut the roof part out to print, and then glue them together after the print, so it would be cheaper.
The flower parts are small and detailed, you can print them separately and glue them together in the end as well.

I didn't paint the house, but I imagine it would look nice if you paint it with different colors.
Jem and the Holograms logo. Whole, and each layer also provided separately if you wish to try multi-color printing or mess around with the design yourself.

description.text:
The standard Google cardboard does not fit the iPhone 6 Plus very well. I also wanted to incorporate straps so that you don't have to hold it to your face.

Take your lenses and magnets from Google cardboard and port them over to this way sexier headset! Print with a raft. Important Do NOT use supports.

comments.text: I have to say that I love this design.  I've printed two other popular designs on Thingiverse and they both suck.  The problem with most of them is that you need a very high level of precision to get any moving parts to work, like gears or knobs.  This one does not have any moving parts so it feels very solid.  Also, I hate having to add/remove rubber bands all the time.  The slot is excellent.  I know it looks like it would print unstable at the 45 degree angle, but mine printed perfectly.

author: 11Sharn11

description.text: This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/loVLvU6zhva
Made with TinkerCAD

After making and using the center aid tool by Connorus (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:725344) I found my drill press wasn't drilling in the exact center of my parts. I needed the holes to be precise so I made a version for my drill press. It uses 1/4 inch bolts to hold the arms and two 5/8 bolts to mount it to my drill press. The mounting holes are 9 inches apart on center or you can use whatever clamps you have. If this is different from your table I included the Sketchup file so you can modify if needed. To center simply clamp the bit with the arms and lock the base in place. I made it with puzzle pieces so I could fit it on the Simple Metal. They fit tight and need to be shaved down to fit together. Even if you have a larger printer and can print it in one piece I would leave it the way it is so you can replace the middle if you ever need to.

Printed on a simple metal at 15% infill and seems to hold up well but after using it for a bit the arms seem to be getting worn out so i think 50% would be enough although I have not tried this yet. There is also a tab off to the side which is for a stop rod mount. There are files for use with a caliper or without. I used my phone camera to center the stop rod by touching the rod to the tip of the drill bit and locking it in place then simply set the caliper to zero. Some of the holes need to be drilled for the rod i used a 1/4 inch drill bit but for the bolts use a smaller bit or else there will be nothing for the bolt to grab onto.

If you modify it to fit your table the top arm mounting holes must be the same distance as the center mount holes for the lower arms. If you do make the top arms longer you can make the lower arms longer just check to make sure they don't hit when turned.

I think it may actually be better to get aluminum angle stock so you can clamp the part in place and use those for the top arms but I haven't gotten around to trying that out that yet.

2 5/8 bolts and threaded knobs to mount to table
4 1.5 inch long 1/4 inch nuts and bolts to mount top arms
2 1/4 inch nuts and bolts to mount lower arms not sure what size i used but i did have to cut them shorter so the part being drilled would sit flat.
1 1/4" rod for stop mount and three 1 inch long 1/4" screws to secure it

comments.text: I added files for the stop mount and a version for using a caliper on it.

title: Parametric Mini Modular Framing System - Corner Block and Rail

description.text:
This is a customize-able version of the original Mini Modular Framing System: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:40611

I loved the original, but wanted something that would fit my pieces of acrylic that I want to use to make a light box/light table. I tried to make these match the original, and they're pretty close. I changed the inside fillet to a chamfer, because filleting in OpenSCAD is annoying. Enjoy, and thanks again to idea_beans for the original concept!

Note: the basic rendering shown in the Customizer will show a lot of artifacts on the filleted edges. These will disappear when you actually render the object.

UPDATE: The corner piece was rendering too short; the high was off by the amount of the Corner Radius. This has been fixed and the file re-uploaded.

UPDATE 2: Corner piece was still too short! It's really fixed now!

description.text:
This is the final release of my Two-Up Extruder Fan Mount and now includes the fan duct.

See the Instructions for more details on how to print and assembly it.

=============================

If you print one of this, please take your time to take some pictures and tell me what you think of it and how it worked.

=============================

I've made this today, and noticed that this duct can't hold the air flow of my 40mm fan.
I'll have to make my way into fluids mechanics and re-design it, so it can work efficiently.
Hope to update it ASAP.

Go to the link and download the Main Plate and the Fan Mount Plate, join them with some drops of super glue as show in pictures.

Download the Fan Duct and join it to the previous step assembly, you can use super glue or the same cable tie you'll use for the 40mm Fan.

=============================

To print the Fan Duct you should rotate it on the X-Axis by 135º degrees, it should be printed by the flat face. You shouldn't need to use support.

comments.text:
I've made this today, and noticed that this duct can't hold the air flow of my 40mm fan.
I'll have to make my way into fluids mechanics and re-design it, so it can work efficiently.

title: Frameless Hanger for 3/16" Foam Core Prints

description.text:
So you've got some artwork mounted on 3/16 inch foam board, but you don't want to bother with matting and framing or you just prefer the minimal look. Here's what you do:

  1. Print four of these hangers.
  2. Slip them over the corners of your foam board.
  3. Thread them together with string and tie snugly.
  4. Display!

Partly inspired by Greg Fishback's frameless picture hanger. Designed in Onshape. View or copy the public document Frameless Hanger for 3/16" Foam Core Prints.

Don't have a printer? Consider buying a set from me on Etsy!

I printed mine with 0.3 mm layers, 3 perimeters, and no infill. No supports are needed but I did use a small brim to ensure a good stick. I used green PLA because that's what I've got, but you may want to choose a color that complements your artwork.

remixed_from.author: Armatec
remixed_from.title: Open Source Robotic Arm (Lite Arm i2)

description.text:
Files to be considered for merging with future Lite Arm i2 releases.

What does each file do?

Visit the Instructions tab for a list of each file's purpose. These files are generally created to be drop-in replacements for originals in the Lite Arm, pick and choose what you want.

Where are the rest of the files?

Visit the original Lite Arm i2, also listed under Remixed From -->
It has all of the base files which allow you to print your own servo-controlled robotic arm.

What is the Lite Arm i2?

Lite Arm i2 is an open source project by Lance Pierson (Armatec) to create a low cost, mini industrial robotics arm.

I want to build one!

  • Check out cwthoma's mod files. They are an excellent resource.
  • Images to help you assemble the beast

Node.JS Server

I'm also working on a nodejs instance that will run on a Raspberry Pi to provide a small Access Point that controls the robotic arm.

Source on github.

Details on this wiki.

Status

Done

  • Make Lite Arm printable on a 150x150mm print bed

WIP

  • Improve documentation for assembly and purchasable hardware.
  • Redesign 21B to have a more solid connection, use less plastic.

Backlog

  • Create laser files so that flat parts can be cut (much cheaper than printing!)
  • Modify parts to use NEMA14/17 stepper motors
  • Modify parts to use 608ZZ bearings. These are used for roller skates and are cheaper + easier to get.
  • Create Node.JS webapp for Arduino+rpi+pwm shield.

21B_SPLIT_X

A kludge to allow for printing the i2 arm on a 150x150mm print bed. Replace the original 20/21B with this. Print all three parts twice and bolt together as shown (use some tape or glue to improve rigidity, I'm working on a better solution).

printingChecklist

A simple list of the 30 some odd .stl files which have to be printed to wind up with a working Lite Arm. Print this out, keep it with the printed parts, and mark off each one that finishes.

This was inspired by a carabiner type clip that would tend to open when and force was applied. The idea is that the tendency to open works in both directions and should draw the clip back closed.

It may require some breaking. Printing at the current size did not for me but printing at 2x produced a much better clip in my opinion.

I think a definite way to improve it would be to make the top-end triangular rather than round. Also, I need to find a way to add a bit more mass to the side which is tapered (which was done due to printing limitations.

author: virtualight

description.text:
Baseplate is similar to:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:96158
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:96388
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:97622 To be printed with 100% fill, 3 shells, 0,1mm filament layer height, centered on the printerbed head up, with raft and supports. With 5mm holes, just like GoPro screws.

Drawn with Blender
http://www.blender.org

I was designing a magazine_holster/hard_mag_pouch and figured I might as well make some replacements for my current Blackhawk! holster/pouch that I have. The good news is that this means I am getting very close to releasing the new design! It will be called the "Universal Magazine Holster" and it is designed to replace the soon-to-be obsolete "Glock Magazine Holster". If you have seen my magazine holster and are going to print it I urge you to hold off because this new design is literally right around the corner (I'm in TN and will print/test the prototype when I get back to MI).

Without further ado, here are replacement parts for your factory magazine holster (Blackhawk! compatible).

P.S.: Blackhawk! makes a great product and neither of these parts have failed on mine. I also ran this replacement belt clip on my factory mag holster in a few competitions and I think it's a suitable replacement should yours break. I want to make my own open source magazine holster/hard_pouch and these were close enough I figured I could get some practice with new software by modeling them.

Unfortunately, to get these parts to work effectively (they are highly dependent on print orientation) supports are necessary (groan). ABS, Polypropylene, or something else with some flexibility is probably necessary, I didn't even bother testing PLA.

Print the retention bar (UniMag_Ret_BH.stl) with 100% infill, 1 shell and whatever layer height with RAFT and SUPPORTS. It sucks, I know, but at least ABS is easier to clean off.

Print the Blackhawk! compatible belt clip (UniMag_Clip1.1.stl) rotated in a similar fashion as the retention bar so that it doesn't flex across multiple layers causing delamination when you stretch it to put it on your belt.

title: Easy Mendel Open Y Carriage (w detachable print bed)

description.text:
This open Y carriage is "designed" to allow an ordinary clothes iron to be used for heating the bed. It can be easily removed (when cold), plus it makes connecting and tensioning the y axis belts heaps easy.
Originally, I had a few more ideas of where it was going, but as I don't have many special tools, and I wanted to print more than bother too much, I ended up with this. As it has mainly been a hack without a clear path, I didn't take heaps of photos on the way.
It would be easier to build with a drill press, although with a drill press there are probably better designs anyway.
Tools required are a hacksaw and a hand drill. Steady hand optional.

Need:
about a metre of M8 threaded rod (or 5/16 or whatever else is left over)
24 M8 nuts (and some washers as appropriate)
2x 140mm 20mmx40mm wood
M6 (or smaller) bolts/threaded rod, and at least 8 nuts
about 500mm of U Channel Aluminium which holds M8 nuts snuggly in the "U"
some 3mm aluminium sheet for print bed
2x 32mm Foldback clips
2x 19mm foldback clips
Y Carriage bushings/bearings as normal. Cut four (4) M8 threaded to the length of the width of your print bed will be. For fun My Prusa frame vertexes are 250mm apart so I made these 240mm - but haven't figured out how to (or needed) use all that print area anyway. Cut two (2) sections of U Channel aluminium the length of your bed (me - 240mm). These could be shorter, but doesn't hurt to be this long. cut two (2) lengths of the 20mm x 40mm wood to 140mm. Drill holes at both ends of the U Channel. You can choose how best to do this. I find measuring once and drilling 2 or 3 times not an issue. That the nuts fit snugly into the U of the Channel means if you drill the holes too large they are automatically centred. to make sure they are mostly square I did drilled three ends and then bolted the end with two holes together so that the last hole lines up with its 'partner'. Do a similar thing with the wood pieces, making the holes travelling through the widest section of the piece - ie its a 40mm 'deep' hole. Once again with a hand drill this is a pain, but if you make the hole larger then nuts will square it for you. Connect the 2 pieces of U Channel together with threaded rod to make a square shape (top of "U" facing out - IMPORTANT), with two sets of nut on the inside to lock them in place. Do the same with the wood, making a rectangle. Since the lengths of threaded rod should be the width of your aluminium print bed, the U Channel and the wood should line up to some degree. Now line up your print bed with the U Channel piece and the wood piece. Adjust the nuts on the threaded rod such that the edges of the bed, the U Channel and the wood are flush and lock the nuts. Now line the two shapes so that the wooden part is centred down the length of the U Channel piece. Clamp with whatever is at hand. Put the print bed to the side for later. By eye (or "measurement" if you're like that), drill two holes into the wood, about 32mm from either end, such that as you go through the wood you will hit the U Channel at a point where your M6 or otherwise bolts will go and can fit a nut. For this step you might like to also consider how you'd like to level your bed. I tried using bolts and was considering springs, but talking to others it looks like the printer itself is pretty level and so the 'levelling nuts' and as low as they go are redundant, therefore the U Channel is bolted directly to the wood. Attach your bushing as you would normally. Generally mine fit between the vertical M8 threaded rod and the vertical M6 "levelling" bolts. Eventually I will replaced these with linear bearings, but is irrelevant. Now spread the y axis smooth rods apart until they are the distance of your bushings or bearing. Mine are about 190mm apart. Jam the Y Carriage on. Loop the y axis belts around the M8 threaded rod which holds the wood together and use the 32mm foldback clip around the loop to hold in place. Adjust as appropriate by loosening and reapplying the clips. Test it moves freely. Slid your aluminium print bed on. As we used it to align things before the U Channel will line up with the edge and using the 19mm fold back clips, attach. This could also hold glass as well with a larger foldback clip. Done-la. Almost... Eventually I will be (counter sink) bolting an iron to the bottom of the aluminium. I have a cheap one ($13 - the ones they sell to students). And I have been cutting the plastic parts off such that the 240V is protected, but fits in the space available. Maybe photos later. For the time being, as it is winter in Oz and the bed is too cold for the first layer to stick nicely, before I start, I sit an ordinary clothes iron on the top of the bed and let that heat up. This print bed is easily detachable for cleaning etc. With an iron attached it may be a little fiddley. A change of orientation of the M6 bolts or using threaded rod will allow the easy removal of the U Channel section. Although, it's not clear if there is a need for this.

comments.text: I like the under carriage and belt clamps enough that I'd like to include it in a design I'm working on but I will have them be printed instead of wood block. I'm not sure about the upper part. Its a lot of material and weight. I do like that you can remove the bed and it LOOKS great. Thanks for sharing.

title: Redsalamander's Extruder
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I started with a QUBD extruder and printed a few different upgrades for it. The extruder this is based on was reliable and I used it till about a year ago as a direct drive. On my newer printers I changed the design so that instead of a heatsink and fan mounted to a small cooling block on the motor, I made a large heatsink with fan that the barrel screwed into and the motor and mounted on top. I later changed this to a bowden design and this design can still be mounted as both a direct drive and a bowden. The arm has however changed significantly from the original. the biggest change is the bearing mount now requires a 8mm shaft for the bearing about 15mm long. The spring I use is a much larger diameter one and I source it from RC model cars suspension shock absorbers smaller springs can still be used but you may need to add a cutout to the arm for it. the frame mount is to mount it on a 25mm frame ( I use 25mm square tube aluminum frames on my machines) you may need to design your own to suit your requirements. If you do please feel free to send then and I will include it in the files.

Pictures attached are;
The evolution of the design over time
The assembled extruder close up and entire setup.
The bearing grove for reference

If you want to see more and how I create prints and 3D designs like this check out my YouTube channel.
https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCSHUc93NXGwBacoIDDqPU2w

This can be used as direct drive or Bowden drive, I have used it as both, to implement as Bowden is far simpler.
Required to complete:

  1. You will need a 608 bearing probably with a grove cut into it but that depends on your drive gear,
  2. A 8mm shaft 15mm long
  3. A tension spring. I use an HPI RC car's suspension spring, the reason is they come in different strengths so you can adjust for more or less tension.
  4. Assorted M3 screws 4x 20mm 2x 30mm 2x nuts and washers to adjust if needed. To mount the frame mount on a frame I use 2x 50mm screws with nuts getting them in M3 is not always easy so you can use larger diameter if you need to.
  5. 4mm OD PTFE tube, it’s what I use for the Bowden tube and in this case it lines the arm that feeds the filament to the drive gear.
    Assembly:
    Cut the grove into the bearing just a little off the center the grove should be 2mm – 2.5mm wide but can be rather shallow only 1mm deep is fine. This is to guide the filament and keep it inline. If this grove is wrong the filament will jump off the drive gear and jam.
    Insert the 4mm ptfe tube into the arm cut it about 3mm from the arm and cut a grove for the bearing to rest on the filament.
    Insert the 8mm shaft into the arm and mount the bearing. The grove should line up with the ptfe liner opening. If it does not flip it over and see if it’s better. (That’s why it’s cut just a little off center) you can put a washer between the bearing an arm to shim it if you need to however try not to.
    The longer M3 screws go through the mount clamp and the motor mount this clamps the Bowden tube the filament exits the extruder with to the hot end. If you want there is a cutout for a m3 nut you can thread over the Bowen tube to hold it tighter but it’s not needed, you may actually find you want to back off the clamp as it can squash the filament.
    The shorter screws are for the arm and top of the motor mount. On some of my extruders I used a longer 40mm screw and a sprint to push the arm onto the stepper motor. Also not needed but an option.
    The other 2 shorter screw are to screw the mount to the frame mount. For your printer it may be different so you may need to find what works for you. Even cable ties can work but may not be pretty.
    What to watch out for:
    If the grove in the bearing is a problem the filament will jump off the gear. This should not be a problem with a grooved gear. Don’t cut a grove into the gear rather cut wider or deeper on the bearing. 2.5mm wide 1mm deep.

title: Eaglez... with Moving Beaks that BITE!  (No support required)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
Eaglez continue on from my popular Sharkz and Crocz.

Eaglez stand up and can be used to hold cards, bite bags closed and more... check out all the images.

This is another fun print in place / one piece print with moving parts. Just squeeze the back and chest parts together to open the beak and bite whatever is nearby...

No support is required... leave it turned completely off. Refer to the instructions provided and images for more details.

Note: This prints really well on a Replicator 2 and 5th Generation MakerBot's with PLA. The only thing to check after printing is that the beak fully opens. If your machine doesn't bridge as well as mine / others you may need to remove a fraction of material from the jaw channel. The alternative is to scale the model up by 5-10% which will increase clearances.

And... if you like this check out all my other designs!

Note: Download my similar designs as follows...

'Z-REX' http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1594269

Woodpeckerz http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1155168

Crocz http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:941177

Sharkz http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:910216

Catz http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:988088

You can alter he strength of the bite by changing the number of shells and amount of infill. MakerBot user recommendations are:

Replicator 2: Std. 0.2mm resolution / 3 shells / 30% fill / Raft / NO SUPPORT

5th Generation Models: Std. 0.2mm resolution / 4 shells / 35% fill / Raft / NO SUPPORT

If you want a weaker or stronger bite change the shells / infill to suit.

At standard size 'Eaglez' will bite okay onto little fingers. If you want to bite bigger fingers uniformly scale up as required (125% should bite most thumbs okay).

My son wanted to play dominoes and we found our set had one card missing. I looked on Thingiverse and only found a laser cut version http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:512 So I made a set for my ToM. 4 plates of Dominoes making a 6 dot set. Although I created this yesterday, I didn't publish it until today, I notice in the meantime that Joerg has created another set http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:9652. Great minds think alike Joerg! Now you have a choice...

Print each set and play. These are scaled for a 100mm x 100mm print size change SCAD file line to resize them.
setIndex, dotSize, dotSpace, thickness set(setNumber,2.5,6,4); If you want to use these for Domino Rally, you should increase the thickness to about 6mm to give yourself a chance to get them standing. Dominoes is a common Pub game in the UK (although it's dying out) there are several variants of play, my son and I play 5s & 3s. If you'd like to know the rules http://www.pagat.com/tile/wdom/fives_and_threes.html is a good introduction. Update:
I have added a set that go up to 9 dots for those who'd like more than 6.

title: finally upgrade for trapezoidal screw for 3Drag/K8200 V3

description.text:
With this thing you can change the default screw (M8) with a trapezoidal srew 10x2 D. You must not move the motor and installation is really simple. You can read more here (Italian blog):

http://www.lillia.net/hack-barra-trapezoidale-asse-z-per-3dragk8200/

OLD VERSION:
bill of materials:
-1 trapezoidal screw 10x2 D
-printed parts
-1 coupler 5-10mm (for motor-screw)
-2 trapezoidal nut (one for moving the carriage and the other to secure the screw above)
-1 ball bearing (10mm int - 31mm ext)

EDIT 03/11/2015
NEW VERSION
I have add the new version for the support. Now is specular. I've use the new trapezoidal nut, hand made. The new bill of materials:
-1 trapezoidal screw 10x2
-1trapezoidal nut 10x2
-2 nut M5
-printed support
-1 flexible coupler
If you want you can buy the items here:
http://www.ebay.it/itm/-/221930860532?

EDIT 15/06/2016
The new version is V3. Now i'he improved the anti-backlash system. Upload the new draw. We have eliminate the flexible coupler, now the screw is on motor. For more info see photos ;)
We redesigned all, starting from 0, to improve performance. You can buy the kit here:
http://www.ebay.it/itm/Kit-Upgrade-asse-z-3Drag-K8200-3D-printer-/222132535174?

add new photos
bill of materials

add new nut
add new
-15/06/2016
add new files
change all

3Drag - K8200

author: johnbiehler

description.text:
The helmet for my rockman-EXE cosplay.
after designing I decided I'm not going to print it because my printer can only print 10 cm high, the sliced pieces do fit in my printer when rotated but then I need loads of supports and it will take up as much as 1 KG of fillament to print. It was designed with 3d-printing in mind so I shouldn't let the design go to waste.

original non-sliced design is also included for remixing.

scale every piece to 1000% (yes I designed them in centimetres but it was saved as millimetres, so just scale it up in slic3r).
then print every piece and glue them together with super-adhesive glue. afterwards get some cheap spray-paint and some tape and tape the parts that don't need colouring and use the spray-paint to apply the correct colouring.
Remade this strimmer attachment because the original broke.

comments.author: FarrisGoldstein

comments.text: We use Cura a lot here, and with the PLA we tend to do 2 times layer height separation on Z but not more then .3mm. and .8mm on the XY.  We also favor lines for PLA instead of Grid. For these prints on the Bukito it's the same material due to the single nozzle.  Hope that helps.

The Plastruder MK4 is the latest extruder design for MakerBot machines. We've fixed a couple of bugs, and improved the design to be more robust. A quick summary of the changes:
  • Motor shaft support bearing
  • Fully attached dino supports
  • Better machined parts (heater barrel, nozzle, etc.)
  • Motor is more firmly attached to housing
Full instructions available here: http://wiki.makerbot.com/plastruder-mk4

Has anybody tried extruding solder with this?
There are plenty of solders and metal alloys that melt below the max temperature of 260C, such as Sn Ag3.0 Cu0.5 with a melting point of 217-220C.
I can think of plenty of uses for being able to extrude metal; parts not requiring high temperatures or qualities not posessed by these alloys could be cast using the extruded part to make a master mold, but personally the ability to make simple, cheap metal parts would be quite nice.

description.text:
After seeing the original, I thought, I've always wanted to play with something like that.
This thing isn't so much a derivation of the original, as much as a reconstitution.  It provides for a good parametric basis for creating other such things.
You can specify the size of the bar in one place, and the handles and grippers will adjust accordingly.
The arm has a cutout to reduce the amount of plastic used to print the thing.  This is a good savings, and in these sizes, it doesn't really change the strength dynamics.
The handle and grip are a friction/slip fit.  If you want permanence, simply glue it on.  If you want the 'gripper' to be able to rotate, then just make the opening wider, or come up with your own gripper.
A good strategy might be to put a dimple inside the gripper, or the handle, to grab onto the hole in the linkage (arm).
I thought about printing a pin.  But really, a 3mm piece of filament makes for a fine pin.  I'm whimping out of course, and perhaps I'll add one later.

1) Print an even number of 'linkage' segments (2, 4, 6)
2) Assemble your links by placing a pin in the middle of two pieces and pins in the ends of pieces if you have more than 2, to form an "accordian"
3) Print a couple of handles, and place them on one end
4) Print a couple of grippers, and place them on the other end
5) Play with your new toy See the original for a nice picture, and look at how it goes together. The .scad and .stl provide for easy mash-up fodder.

comments.text: The gripper part  is deceptively difficult to design isn't it.  Not only do you have to offset based on the thickness of the bar and the orientatin of the bar, you also have to worry about the breadth of the bar and the contact angle of the gripper.

title: M6 nut/screw adapter for SKB 19" rack systems

description.text:
I was pressing an old SKB rack flight case back into action, only to find I was missing some of the proprietary nuts and screws. I'm a bit of a cheapskate so didn't want to spend £14 on 12 nuts/screws (on left of my picture) - and I had a lot of M6 nuts and bolts lying around (which cost pennies from any hardware store), so I figured there must be a way to use them in my SKB rack :)
Print a few of these little guys out, drop your M6 hex nuts into the lovingly-crafted hole (a little spot of Superglue will help keep them there), and slide them onto your rack. Use M6 screw to fix from the front.
I'm not saying they're as robust as the official SKB solution, but as a set-and-forget option, it works for me. Hope it's useful for someone else out there :)

Created in Sketchup Make.
Printed on UP! Plus 2 printer in ABS

description.text: My daughter once said she wasn't very good at drawing things, so we worked on an easy to remember bunny design. Even though she's all grown up now she still remembers the bunny and draws it on my birthday cards. I thought I'd build the bunny in 3D and upload him so that others can print him out.

The model is built in Tinkercad and I've included a few versions of the
head for easier printing. There's a combined model if you want to add
your own support, as well as separate body and head models. I've
added a head with meshmixer support for the teeth and ears. Also
there is a version with easy to print ears. The bunny is in blue glow-in-the-dark plastic and painted with basic acrylics.
Another stackable card holder with a lid that covers 6 holders
use as you please. the lid can be modified along the one axis to fit in as many holders as you like
I have rotated 45 degrees the original for easy printing

title: Micro Ublox NEO-6M GPS bracket for quad copter

description.text:
Gps bracket for the Micro Ublox NEO 6M. It's designed for being mounted on a Quad copter on a 6mm carbon rod (in order to move it away from signal noise sources). The design allows the gps to snap in place.

3D printed with perfect result on a Ultimaker 2 3D printer.

Can be printed on any 3D printer in a plastic material (PLA, ABS, Nylon, etc). I printed it standing upright on the build plate (the default orientation). This requires support structures to be printed, but the result was great.
